CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Violation of Art. 11;Not necessary to examine Art. 14+10;Just satisfaction  reserved
TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON , a NORP national born in DATE , lives in Jever in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG After studying literature and languages at ORG for DATE , during which time she became a member of ORG ( ORG - " ORG " ) , in DATE she sat the examination to become a secondary - school teacher ( wissenschaftliche Prüfung für das PERSON an PERSON ) . She did her teaching practice ( ORG für das PERSON ) from DATE at ORG in GPE . In DATE she sat the second ORG examination to become a secondary - school teacher ( zweite PERSON für das PERSON an PERSON ) and obtained a post from DATE as a teacher ( Studienrätin ) , with the status of probationary civil servant ( Beamtenverhältnis auf Probe ) , in a ORG secondary school in GPE . On DATE , before the end of her probationary period , she was appointed a permanent civil servant ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . PERSON taught NORP and LANGUAGE . In an assessment report drawn up in DATE her capabilities and work were described as entirely satisfactory and it was stated that she was held in high regard by her pupils and their parents and by her colleagues .

CARDINAL . ORG After a preliminary investigation , the ORG regional council ( PERSON ) issued an order ( GPE ) on DATE instituting disciplinary proceedings against the applicant on the ground that she had failed to comply with the duty of loyalty to LAW ( " duty of political loyalty " - politische GPE ) that she owed as a civil servant under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG ( PERSON - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . She had , it was said , engaged in various political activities on behalf of the ORG since the autumn of DATE and in particular had stood as the ORG candidate in the DATE elections to ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG The " indictment " ( PERSON ) of CARDINAL DATE , drawn up in connection with the disciplinary proceedings , specified CARDINAL public , political activities that the applicant had engaged in for the ORG , such as distributing pamphlets , representing the ORG at political meetings , being a party official in a constituency and standing in the federal elections of DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the proceedings were stayed in order to widen the investigations to include further instances of the applicant 's political activity that had come to light in the meantime .
CARDINAL . ORG In a supplementary " indictment " of CARDINAL DATE PERSON was accused of also failing to comply with her duties as a civil servant in that :
( a ) she had been a member of ORG " ( PERSON ) of ORG regional branch ( Bezirksorganisation ) of the ORG since DATE ; and
( b ) she had taken part in and addressed the ORG 's CARDINALth party congress , held from DATE in GPE , as Chairperson ( PERSON ) of the PERSON / Friesland local branch of the party .

CARDINAL . ORG After a further stay of proceedings on DATE , a second supplementary " indictment " was drawn up on DATE , which specified CARDINAL other political activities considered incompatible with the applicant 's civil - servant status , namely :
( a ) her candidature for the ORG in the elections to ORG on DATE ;
( b ) the fact that she was still a member of ORG " of ORG regional branch of the ORG ;
( c ) the fact that she was still Chairperson of the PERSON / GPE local branch of the ORG ; and
( d ) her participation in the ORG 's CARDINALth party congress from DATE in GPE as a party delegate .
CARDINAL . ORG By an order of CARDINAL DATE the ORG regional council notified the applicant that she had been temporarily suspended from her post , stating in particular as follows :

" Although you knew the views of your superiors and the case - law of the disciplinary courts you have nevertheless , over a considerable period of time , deliberately violated your duty of oyalty . For a permanent civil servant that is anextraordinarily serious breach of duty . Civil servants , whosestatus is founded on a special relationship of trust with ORG and who , by taking the oath , have vowed to uphold the lawand freedom , destroy this basis of trust , which is essential forthe continuation of their relationship with their employer[Dienstverhältnis ] , if they deliberately support a party whoseaims are incompatible with the free democratic constitutionalsystem . This is the position in the present case . "
CARDINAL . ORG From DATE PERSON was paid CARDINAL per cent of her salary ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Before ORG of ORG ( PERSON des Verwaltungsgerichts ) the applicant , who by her own account has been a member of the ORG since DATE , argued that her conduct could not amount to a failure to fulfil her duties as a civil servant . By being a member of the party and carrying out activities on its behalf she had availed herself of the right of all citizens to engage in political activity . She had always carried out such activity within the law and within the limits laid down in the LAW . Her action to promote peace within GPE and in its external relations and her combat against neo - fascism were in no way indicative of an anti - constitutional stance . The ORG , whose aims had always been wrongly alleged ( but never proven ) to be anti - constitutional , took part lawfully in the process of forming political opinion in GPE . Lastly , according to a report issued by ORG on DATE , the institution of disciplinary proceedings against civil servants on account of their political activities on behalf of a party that had not been banned breached ORG ( ILO ) Convention No . CARDINAL concerning discrimination in respect of employment and occupation . It also violated Article CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed applications by PERSON to have the proceedings stayed and witnesses examined . The division ordered that all the " charges " against PERSON be dropped except those concerning her membership , as such , of the ORG and of ORG " of ORG regional branch , her chairing of the PERSON branch of the ORG and her candidature in the elections to ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On the merits , ORG held that the applicant had failed to comply with her duty of political loyalty and ordered her dismissal as a disciplinary measure . It granted her a sum equivalent to MONEY of her pension entitlement at that date , to be paid for a DATE period .
The division found in the first place that neither ORG . CARDINAL nor the recommendations made in ORG report of CARDINAL DATE constituted a bar to the opening of disciplinary proceedings .

It considered that active membership of a political party that pursued anti - constitutional aims was incompatible with a civil servant 's duty of political loyalty . The ORG 's aims , as described in the GPE programme of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , were clearly opposed to the free democratic constitutional system of GPE . A party could be held to be anti - constitutional even if it had not been banned by ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) under LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Through the active role which she played within the ORG the applicant had therefore clearly supported aims that were contrary to LAW .

ORG added that the rule , laid down in the first sentence of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , according to which no one may be prevented from taking office as a member of parliament , could not justify the applicant 's standing as the ORG candidate in regional elections . This rule did not apply to measures , such as disciplinary proceedings , which initially had a different purpose and restricted the freedom to stand for election to , and to sit as a member of , parliament only as an indirect and unavoidable consequence of their implementation .

The duty of political loyalty , which admittedly restricted civil servants ' fundamental rights , was one of the traditional principles of the civil service and had constitutional status by virtue of LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It followed that this duty took precedence over the provisions of international instruments such as LAW .

The applicant had moreover carried out her political activities despite being familiar with the case - law establishing that active membership of the ORG was incompatible with the duty of political loyalty . She must have been aware , at the latest once ORG PERSON ) had delivered its judgment of DATE , which was published in an official education - authority circular and was brought to the attention of the applicant in person , that her conduct was in breach of her duties ( pflichtwidriges PERSON ) . PERSON had accordingly to be dismissed for having betrayed the relationship of trust between herself and her employer . Throughout the disciplinary proceedings she had moreover repeatedly indicated that she intended to continue her political activities for the ORG despite the warnings she had received . The fact that she had done her work satisfactorily for DATE and that she had been held in high regard by her pupils and their parents alike was immaterial .

ORG finally ordered that PERSON should be paid MONEY of her pension allowance for DATE . It did so in recognition of the fact that apart from her breach of the duty of loyalty PERSON had always performed her duties unexceptionably and enthusiastically and needed some income to be protected from immediate hardship .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the above judgment with ORG , reiterating her previous arguments ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . ORG In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed PERSON appeal and upheld ORG judgment in all respects .

It pointed out that , by carrying out activities on behalf of the ORG , the applicant had breached the duty of political loyalty that she owed in accordance with LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW , taken together with LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG . Under those provisions , civil servants must at all times bear witness to the free democratic constitutional system within the meaning of LAW and uphold that system . They must unequivocally dissociate themselves from groups who criticise , campaign against and cast aspersions on the State , its institutions and the existing constitutional system . As a result of her activities as a member of the ORG the applicant had failed to satisfy these requirements . The ORG 's political aims were incompatible with that system .

The fact that ORG had not banned the ORG did not prevent other courts from finding that the party was anti - constitutional , as ORG and ORG itself had done convincingly in judgments of CARDINAL DATE and DATE . An analysis of the still current GPE programme made by ORG in their book on the ORG 's methods and objectives ( PERSON , CARDINALnd edition , DATE ) showed that the party , which aimed to establish a regime similar to that existing in the communist countries around DATE , continued to be guided by the principles of PERSON , PERSON and PERSON . Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW and the corresponding legislation of ORG securing the right to take office as a member of parliament did not set limits on the duty of political loyalty , since those provisions were not applicable to impediments resulting from disciplinary proceedings . The court held that the applicant 's reference to LAW CARDINAL of LAW , which secured the right to freedom of expression , was not relevant as the provisions governing the civil service mentioned in LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW had to be regarded as general laws within the meaning of LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Similarly , ORG had ruled that a decision by a competent authority relating to admission to the civil service did not amount to an interference with freedom of expression . The same approach applied in cases where a person had already been appointed to a permanent civil service post .

PERSON conduct had been unlawful . By holding such a senior political post within the ORG , she necessarily espoused anti - constitutional aims and had therefore to be considered to be opposed to LAW herself , although she proclaimed her attachment to LAW . It was not possible to support both systems at the same time .

Even though PERSON sought above all to achieve some of the ORG 's short - term objectives such as reducing unemployment , promoting peace and eliminating so - called ORG ( prohibitions on pursuing various occupations ) , this did not mean that her conduct was not culpable . The ORG 's aims were admittedly not all anti - constitutional ; some of them were compatible with LAW . However , civil servants could not , as a means of furthering their own political objectives , make use of a party with anti - constitutional aims and help it to come to power . In this connection ORG referred to the following observations made by ORG ) in a judgment of DATE , adding that it adopted them as it was convinced that exactly the same reasoning applied to the case before it :

" It is admittedly possible to accept the view of ORG [ ORG ] that the official in question does not seek to change the system of government of ORG by the use of force and that this declaration can not be dismissed as mere ' lip - service ' . It is also possible to accept his claim that he is mainly concerned with correcting what he perceives to be a discrepancy between the principles laid down in the LAW and their application in practice in GPE and that he is profoundly sincere in his wish to establish a society that is more just , particularly in the economic sphere . However , contrary to the view taken by ORG , this does not mean that he is entitled to see in the ORG the political grouping through which he believes he can achieve his ideal political order . It appears doubtful whether the view of the LAW espoused by the official and described above reflects accurately the principles enshrined in LAW . It is not necessary to resolve that question here . In its judgment banning the former ORG ( ORG ) ( BVerfGE CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) , ORG held that not only the ' tactics of conflict ' employed by the former ORG but also the different phases of the process leading to attainment of its final objective of ' socialist rule ' [ sozialistische Herrschaft ] , namely proletarian revolution by peaceful or violent means and the triumph of the working class ... , were incompatible with the free democratic constitutional system . [ It ] also stated that intensive propaganda and persistent unrest aimed at establishing - even if this was not to be achieved in the near future - a political regime that was clearly contrary to the free democratic constitutional system inevitably caused direct and immediate harm to that system ... ORG thus also unquestionably held that the transitional stages of this process , which were of indefinite duration [ and which the party sought to impose ] through intensive propaganda and persistent unrest were incompatible with the free democratic constitutional system ( BVerwGE CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . Hence , contrary to the view taken by ORG , the civil servant 's assertion that he did not intend to change ORG political system by violent means , which is moreover consistent with many statements made by his party , is of no legal significance ( BVerwGE DATE , p. CARDINAL ) . "

The court also considered that the applicant 's commitment to changing the ORG 's policies could not exculpate her . The political loyalty owed by civil servants entailed a duty for them to dissociate themselves unequivocally from groups which criticised or cast aspersions on the ORG and the existing constitutional system . The attitude of civil servants who , even if they campaigned within the ORG for the renunciation of aims that were contrary to LAW , showed outside the party , through the political offices they held , that they unreservedly supported its programme and policy , was incompatible with such a duty . For as long as the ORG had not abandoned its anti - constitutional aims , civil servants ' duty of political loyalty prevented them from actively working for it . This remained valid even where it was their intention to bring the party closer to democratic values . Moreover , during the disciplinary proceedings the applicant had declared her unconditional support for the ORG 's aims , as set out in the GPE programme .

Like ORG , ORG found that PERSON had knowingly breached her professional obligations . Although she was aware of the case - law and her superiors ' views on the subject , she had continued and even stepped up her activities on behalf of the ORG . Her dismissal had therefore been justified , since a civil servant who thus persisted in breaching her duties and refusing to see reason ( unbelehrbar ) was no longer capable of serving the ORG , which must be able to rely on its servants ' loyalty to LAW . The court added that such a breach of duty was especially serious in the case of a teacher , who was supposed to teach the children entrusted to her care the fundamental values of the LAW . Parents , who because of compulsory education had to send their children to ORG schools , were entitled to expect the ORG to employ only those teachers who unreservedly supported the free democratic constitutional system . The ORG was under a duty to dismiss teachers who played an active role in an anti - constitutional organisation .

The court added that a radical change in a civil servant 's attitude could affect its assessment of the seriousness of professional misconduct . However , throughout the disciplinary proceedings , far from cutting down on her activities on behalf of the ORG , the applicant had in fact increased them . It followed that a more lenient disciplinary measure , aimed at persuading her to abandon her political activities within the ORG , was bound to fail . Accordingly , it was impossible to continue to employ her as a civil servant and her dismissal was inevitable . Her otherwise blameless conduct in carrying out her teaching tasks did not change the situation in any way , since the basis of trust that was essential for her to continue as a civil servant was lacking .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint ( ORG ) with ORG .
Sitting as a panel of CARDINAL judges , the court decided on DATE not to entertain the constitutional complaint , on the ground that it had insufficient prospects of success .

In ORG view , the competent courts ' analysis was based on the conviction that , by her membership of the ORG and her active role within that party , the applicant had breached her duties as a civil servant . This conclusion was well - founded and in no way arbitrary . After the commencement of the disciplinary proceedings , PERSON had herself stated that there was no point , section or part of the ORG 's programme of which she disapproved , thus endorsing unconditionally the party 's aims set out in the GPE programme . The disciplinary tribunals had been entitled to find that the ORG 's aims were anti - constitutional , notwithstanding the provisions of LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW . Regard being had to the applicant 's intractability in respect of her political loyalty , the disciplinary courts had rightly considered that the basis of trust necessary for PERSON to continue to work as a civil servant was lacking , despite the fact that she had declared herself to be in favour of a change in the party 's policy and had otherwise carried out her teaching tasks in a way that was irreproachable . The applicant 's dismissal had therefore not amounted to a breach of the principle of proportionality as regards her constitutional rights . Accordingly , there had been no violation of LAW paras . CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG From DATE to DATE the applicant worked as a playwright and drama teacher at the GPE regional theatre ( ORG ) in PERSON .

From DATE she was reinstated in her post as a teacher for the ORG education authority . The Land government had beforehand repealed the decree on the employment of extremists in the GPE civil service ( PERSON - also known as the PERSON - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and had published regulations for dealing with " earlier cases " ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . ORG The following provisions of LAW ) are relevant to the instant case :

" ( CARDINAL ) Everyone shall have the right freely to express and disseminate his or her opinions in speech , writing and pictures and freely to obtain information from generally accessible sources . Freedom of the press and freedom of reporting on the radio and in films shall be guaranteed . There shall be no censorship .

( CARDINAL ) These rights shall be subject to the limitations laid down by the provisions of the general laws and by statutory provisions aimed at protecting young people and to the obligation to respect personal honour .
( CARDINAL ) There shall be freedom of art , science , research and teaching . Freedom of teaching shall not release citizens from their duty of loyalty to LAW . "

" ( CARDINAL ) Political parties shall take part in forming the political opinion of the people . They may be freely set up . Their internal organisation must comply with democratic principles . They must render public account of the origin of their income and their assets and of their expenditure .

( CARDINAL ) Parties which , through their aims or the conduct of their members , seek to damage or overthrow the free democratic constitutional system or to endanger the existence of GPE shall be held to be anti - constitutional . The ORG shall determine the question of anti - constitutionality .
( CARDINAL ) Detailed rules shall be laid down by federal laws . "
( CARDINAL ) All NORP shall have an equal right of admission to the civil service according to their suitability , capabilities and professional qualifications .

( CARDINAL ) Enjoyment of civil and political rights , admission to the civil service and the rights acquired within the civil service shall not be contingent on religious belief . No one shall be placed at a disadvantage on account of his or her ' adherence or non - adherence ' to a religious persuasion [ Bekenntnis ] or to an ' ideology ' [ Weltanschauung ] .
( CARDINAL ) The provisions governing the civil service must take into account its traditional principles . "

" No one shall be prevented from taking office as a member of parliament or from performing the duties attaching thereto . No employment contract may be terminated and no one may be dismissed from employment on this ground . "

CARDINAL . ORG By virtue of LAW ( Bundesbeamtengesetz ) and LAW CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( CARDINAL ) of ORG ( General Principles ) Act ( Beamtenrechtsrahmengesetz ) for the ORG , appointments to the civil service are subject to the requirement that the persons concerned " satisfy the authorities that they will at all times uphold the free democratic constitutional system within the meaning of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG According to LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG and section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , third sentence , of ORG ( General Principles ) Act for the ORG , " civil servants must by their entire conduct bear witness to the free democratic constitutional system within the meaning of LAW and act to uphold it " .

CARDINAL . ORG These provisions have been reproduced in the civil service legislation of the Länder , and in particular in LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG ( PERSON ) , which likewise provides that " civil servants must by their entire conduct bear witness to the free democratic constitutional system within the meaning of LAW and act to uphold it " .
CARDINAL . ORG ( Niedersächsische Disziplinarordnung ) contains the following relevant provisions :
" Under this law , measures may be taken against :
( CARDINAL ) officials who have breached their professional duty while having the status of a civil servant ... "
" The disciplinary measures shall be : ... dismissal ... "
" Dismissal shall also entail loss of the right to a salary and of pension rights ... "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Federal Chancellor and the Prime Ministers of the Länder adopted the decree on employment of extremists in the civil service ( PERSON ) ( Bulletin of the Government of GPE no . CARDINAL of DATE , p. CARDINAL ) , which reiterated civil servants ' duty of loyalty to the free democratic constitutional system and provided as follows :

" ... civil servants ' membership of parties or organisations that oppose the constitutional system - and any support given to such parties or organisations - shall ... as a general rule lead to a conflict of loyalty . If this results in a breach of duty [ NORP ] , it shall be for the employer to decide in each case what measures are to be taken . "

CARDINAL . ORG In order to implement the decree , ORG adopted , in particular on DATE , provisions on " political activity by applicants for civil - service posts and by civil servants directed against the free democratic constitutional system " .
CARDINAL . Similar legislation was initially adopted in all the ORG . However , from DATE it was no longer or only partially applied ; in some ORG the relevant legislation was even repealed .

In DATE , as part of their coalition agreement on the formation of a new Government for ORG , the NORP and " Green " parties decided to repeal the decree on employment of extremists in the civil service ; the decree was repealed by a ministerial decision of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Land government took a number of measures relating to the treatment of " earlier cases " , that is to say cases of persons who had been excluded from the civil service or refused admission to it on account of their political activities . The decision made it possible - and this happened in the present case ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) - for civil servants who had been dismissed following disciplinary proceedings to be reinstated in their posts , provided that they satisfied the recruitment and qualification requirements , without , however , entitling them to compensation or to arrears of salary .
CARDINAL . ORG In a leading case of CARDINAL DATE ORG clarified the special duty of loyalty owed by NORP civil servants to the ORG and its LAW :

The tasks of a modern ORG administration are as varied as they are complex and they must be accomplished in an adequate , effective and prompt manner if the political and social system is to function and groups , minorities and individuals are to be able to lead a decent life . That administration must be able to count on a body of civil servants which is united and loyal , which faithfully performs its duties and is thoroughly dedicated to the ORG and the LAW . If civil servants can not be relied upon , society and ORG have no chance in situations of crisis .

It is sufficient to observe that the duty of political loyalty owed by civil servants is the core of civil servants ' duty of loyalty . It does not mean a duty to identify with the aims or a particular policy of the Government in power . It means being prepared to identify with the idea of the ORG which the official has to serve and with the free democratic constitutional order of that ORG based on the rule of law and social justice .

It can not be in the interests of the ORG and society to have civil servants who are entirely uncritical . It is , however , essential that a civil servant approves the ORG - notwithstanding its defects - and the existing constitutional order as it is in force and that he or she recognises that they merit protection , bears witness to them accordingly and is active on their behalf .

ORG The duty of political loyalty - loyalty to the ORG and to the LAW - requires more than an attitude which while formally correct is in fact uninterested , indifferent and , at heart , distant in relation to the ORG and the LAW .

It entails , inter alia , the duty for civil servants to dissociate themselves unequivocally from groups and movements that criticise , campaign against and cast aspersions on that ORG , its institutions and the existing constitutional system .

[ The duty of loyalty owed by a civil servant ] applies to every type of appointment in the civil service , an appointment of fixed duration , an appointment on probation and an appointment subject to revocation as well as an appointment to a permanent post . Nor can there be any difference of treatment in this respect according to the nature of the civil servant 's duties .

The fact that ORG has not exercised its power to declare a party anti - constitutional does not mean that it is impossible to have the conviction - and to express that conviction - that the party in question pursues anti - constitutional aims and must therefore be challenged in the political arena . A party which for instance advocates in its manifesto the dictatorship of the proletariat or approves recourse to force in order to overthrow the constitutional system if the conditions are right , pursues anti - constitutional aims ...

CARDINAL . ORG In judgments of CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG held that civil servants who played an active role in the ORG , for example by holding a post in the party or by standing as its candidate in elections , would be in breach of their duty of political loyalty , because they would necessarily be identifying with the anti - constitutional aims of that party . It followed the same line of reasoning in a judgment of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In its report of CARDINAL DATE the majority of ORG concluded that " the measures taken in application of the duty of faithfulness to the free democratic basic order have in various respects not remained within the limits of the restrictions authorised by DATE , paragraph CARDINAL , of [ ORG ) ] Convention No . CARDINAL " . It also formulated a number of recommendations .

In reply to this report , ORG maintained that the measures taken to ensure that civil servants remained loyal to LAW were not contrary to the relevant provisions of Convention No . CARDINAL and that in any case the recommendations made by ORG were not binding on the NORP State for the purposes of domestic law .
